The big one looks sweet! I made mine a bit more stable by adding more sweep to the outter part of the wing. Still sideslips a bit, but then stabilizes itself just fine.

I added little winglets to mine in the end - I'd imagine any modern non-stealth flying wing ( ok this isn't quite a "flying wing" anymore ) is going to have them anyway. It still has yaw control via spoilers though. I suppose I'd better check it's flight dynamics one day.

> 
> Is there any way to make a flying wing more stable without adding additional vertical surfaces to stabilize it? Seems like flying wings like to slip left and right some. I know about making it more dihedral, but maybe some other way to do that as it seems not enough?
> Are there any documents regarding the stability issues on flying wings like Horten? It seems like the engine housings on [XB-35](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0f/XB-35.jpg) were enough to stabilize it and there were vertical surfaces on [YB-49](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4a/YB49-2_300.jpg) dedicated to do exactly that, but I could not find anything about Horten 229's system of stabilization. Perhaps the side slip (+asymmetrical thrust from the failed engine) killed the test pilot of 229, or were the flaps designed in such way to prevent it at low speeds?
> 
> I'm asking about Horten specifically as it seems to have no apparent stabilizers at all. Will experiment with dihedral some more, but would also like to know what you guys think.
> 
> EDIT: I also know about B-2's, which uses the engine thrust and nozzles (read somewhere on the forums, not sure where) to direct and cancel out the slip, but I'm using propellers, so that's not possible.

The Ho-229 had drag-rudders on the top and bottom of the wing (towards the tip) that controlled the yaw. However, the plane never flew, so there was no testing regarding their efficacy. It's likely that they wouldn't have given the plane a lot of control: I can remember reading somewhere that experts suggested that the design of the plane meant it would be unlikely to enter a flat spin in level flight or light manoeuvres, but tight manoeuvres might lead to the plane entering a stall, and in such cases the pilot wouldn't have a lot of ability to recover the aircraft. I'll try and find the source for you. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

One of the biggest glaring issues I notice with that craft is its wings.

The wings are straight, this is not a good thing for supersonic flight, which you WILL have to achieve in order to get to orbit. Most of the large SSTO designs have quite a bit of lifting surface to get their bulk off the ground and to keep them from having absurd landing speeds. 

Like my current workhorse, which is only a light-medium lifter but I dont need anything larger yet. 

![iVIUKr0.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/iVIUKr0.jpg)

It is a bit of a pig when it goes supersonic but it isnt designed to turn well... it is a cargo craft.

However, it is possible to build an area ruled plane with straight wings. Just alot harder to do, especially when trying to get acceptable wing loading for an SSTO.

> 
> Sooo... does anyone have any suggestions for how to build for reentry? It seems I can make perfectly functional SSTOs but I can't bring them down. General pointers would be helpful.

Airbrakes behind CoM. Their drag keeps you stable, and makes sure you don't go just as fast.

> 
> Also, I'm playing with lifting body aeroshells out of Mk3 hulls but that's not panning out. In that they're violently unstable and don't actually produce any lift. Help here would be appreciated too.

Lifting body only really works at high speeds. May want to reenter, and steer a bit using lifting body, but then land using chutes.

Also, you'll still need stabilizers. And keep your CoM as close to the nose as possible.

That said, my experience with lifting bodies is based on reentering with former rockets. Never actually built a lifting body.
